cleaned_text: Alliance for Natural Health |This article is part of |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) The Alliance for Natural Health (ANH) is an advocacy group founded in 2002 by Robert Verkerk and based in the United Kingdom. ANH was founded to raise funds to finance a legal challenge of the EU Food Supplement Directive. ANH lobbies against regulation of [dietary supplements](/wiki/Dietary_supplement), in favour of pseudo-scientific [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine), and advocates dietary and other lifestyle approaches to health. It also criticizes established science showing that [Megavitamin therapy](/wiki/Megavitamin_therapy) lack any health benefit. History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Alliance_for_Natural_Health&action=edit§ion=1)] The ANH is an advocacy group founded in 2002 by Robert Verkerk and based in the United Kingdom.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] ANH was initially founded to raise funds to finance a legal challenge of the EU Food Supplement Directive.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] The ANH lobbies against the regulation of dietary supplements, in favour of pseudo-scientific alternative medicine, and advocates dietary and other lifestyle approaches to health. It also criticizes scientific research showing that megadoses of vitamins lack any health benefits. Positions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Alliance_for_Natural_Health&action=edit§ion=2)] ANH runs campaigns in favor of [dietary supplements](/wiki/Dietary_supplements), "sustainable healthcare", and traditional medicinal cultures such as [Ayurveda](/wiki/Ayurveda) and [traditional Chinese medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine).Alliance for Natural Health International. It also campaigns against [GMOs](/wiki/GMO), [fluoridation](/wiki/Fluoridation) of drinking water, corporate influence in agriculture, [electromagnetic radiation](/wiki/Electromagnetic_radiation_and_health), and the global harmonisation of the food trade by the United Nations [Codex Alimentarius](/wiki/Codex_Alimentarius) Commission. [Alliance for Natural Health International](http://www.anhcampaign.org/campaigns-background) The ANH believes that negative media publicity about nutrients such as [vitamin E](/wiki/Vitamin_E) are merely a result of misinterpretations over the science. [[1]](#cite_note-1) It also criticises the latest research [[2]](#cite_note-Cochrane_vit_c-2) proposing [vitamin C](/wiki/Vitamin_C) supplementation does not protect against the common cold as having a number of fundamental flaws. [[3]](#cite_note-3) Verkerk has been quoted in newspapers criticizing scientific findings from [JAMA](/wiki/Journal_of_the_American_Medical_Association) and the [Cochrane Collaboration](/wiki/Cochrane_Collaboration), among others, [[4]](#cite_note-Cochrane_Bjelakovic_supplements-4) [[5]](#cite_note-JAMA_Bjelakovic_supplements-5) which found that some antioxidant vitamin supplements may shorten lifespan. [[6]](#cite_note-6) Speaking at the inaugural "Scientific Research in Homoeopathy" conference held by the Complementary Medical Association (CMA) at the [University of Westminster](/wiki/University_of_Westminster) in June 2008, Verkerk said that it was "utterly inappropriate" to use [randomised trials](/wiki/Randomised_controlled_trial) (RCTs) and other [complementary medicines](/wiki/Alternative_medicine), arguing that "as soon as you put someone into a trial situation, you destroy many of the effects that exist between patient and practitioner." [[7]](#cite_note-7) Speaking to the [BBC](/wiki/BBC) in the UK, Verkerk has said that EU standards on health claims favour bigger food companies, adding that big firms who had sufficient resources could play the system and claim health benefits simply by inserting a small amount of an approved ingredient such as Vitamin C into a product. [[8]](#cite_note-8) Legal challenges[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Alliance_for_Natural_Health&action=edit§ion=3)] Legal challenge to European Union Food Supplements Directive[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Alliance_for_Natural_Health&action=edit§ion=4)] In 2004, along with two British trade associations, ANH legally challenged the European Union's Food Supplements Directive [[9]](#cite_note-9) referred to the [European Court of Justice](/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice) by the High Court in London. [[10]](#cite_note-10) The European Court of Justice's Advocate General said that the EU's plan to tighten rules on the sale of [vitamins](/wiki/Vitamins) and [nutritional supplements](/wiki/Nutritional_supplements) should be scrapped [[11]](#cite_note-11) but was overruled by the European Court, which decided that the measures in question were necessary and appropriate for the purpose of protecting [public health](/wiki/Public_health). ANH interpreted the ban as applying only to synthetically produced supplements - and not to vitamins and minerals normally found in or consumed as part of the diet. [[12]](#cite_note-12) The European judges did acknowledge the Advocate General's concerns, stating that there must be clear procedures to allow substances to be added to the permitted list based on scientific evidence. They also said that any refusal to add a product to the list must be open to challenge in the courts. [[13]](#cite_note-13) Legal challenge to European Union Traditional Herbal Medicinal Products Directive[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Alliance_for_Natural_Health&action=edit§ion=5)] In March 2011, ANH announced its intention to launch a legal challenge to the European Union's [Traditional Herbal Medicinal Products Directive](/wiki/European_Directive_on_Traditional_Herbal_Medicinal_Products). The Directive will be challenged first of all in the High Court in London, arguing that it is "disproportionate, non-transparent and discriminatory." ANH then hopes to have the case referred to the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg. [[14]](#cite_note-14) It argues the new rules adversely impact alternative medicine practices such as [Ayurveda](/wiki/Ayurveda) [[15]](#cite_note-15) and that the registration costs are affordable for single herbal products with big markets, such as [echinacea](/wiki/Echinacea), but not for small producers of compound herbal remedies. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Legal challenge to U.S. FDA's adoption of new manufacturing regulations[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Alliance_for_Natural_Health&action=edit§ion=6)] In April 2011, a U.S. federal judge ruled against a legal challenge by ANH to the U.S. [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration)'s adoption of new manufacturing regulations. U.S. District Judge [Beryl Howell](/wiki/Beryl_Howell) found that the regulations "did not exceed the FDA's statutory authority, are not impermissibly vague under the due process clause, and are not arbitrary and capricious under the [Administrative Procedure Act](/wiki/Administrative_Procedure_Act_(United_States))."
